p.s: Description of Pasteurella mairi sp. nov.
Pasteurella mairi (mair'i. M.L. gen. n. mairi, of Mair, named after N. S. Mair, who isolated the organism)
Phenon 5 of Sneath and Stevens (46); Pasteurella sp. strain “Mair” of Kilian et al. (22).
Cells are small nonmotile bacilli and coccobacilli.
Growth is aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, mesophilic.

Surface colonies grown aerobically on sheep blood agar are round, greyish, semitransparent, and about 3 mm in diameter after 48 h at 37°C; they usually have a narrow surrounding zone of hemolysis, occasionally with greening of the erythrocytes.

Notable for being sensitive to malachite green and 1% Teepol and for usually giving a positive ornithine decarboxylase reaction; growth on DNase agar (catalog no. CM321; Oxoid, Ltd., London, England) shows a characteristic orange fluorescence (46).
Other properties are shown in Table 2.
This organism has been isolated from abortion in sows and septic infections in piglets; it may occur in other animals (46).
It is phenotypically similar to P. haemolytica sensu stricto and A. lignieresii (46).
DNA-DNA pairing tests show values of 30 to 50% to some strains of P. aerogenes and P. pneumotropica, but values less than 25% to P. multocida, Pasteurella volantium, and P. ureae (28, 35).
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 43.4 mol% (Tm method) (28).
The type strain is strain dCTC 10699 (= LPHL 5143170 = D1187 = A10 = 68) (28, 46).
In our hands this strain was negative for the tests marked d in Table 1, except for hemolysis and acid production from m-inositol.
